title: Academic Research Code Dependency & Reproducibility Tracker
description: Upload your computational research code files and environment specifications to generate structured reproducibility and dependency reports with checklists. Designed for academic researchers to track code dependencies, environment snapshots, and reproducibility status with ease and minimal DevOps expertise.
inputLabel: Upload code files and environment specs (e.g., requirements.txt, Dockerfiles) and optionally paste experiment metadata JSON or notes.
outputLabel: Generated reproducibility and dependency report with environment snapshot summary and reproducibility checklist.
systemPrompt: You are a specialized assistant for academic research software developers. Accept only valid code files (.py, .R, .yaml, .txt) and environment spec files. Also accept optional JSON experiment metadata. Validate all inputs strictly. Refuse uploads with disallowed file types or invalid metadata. Produce a clear, structured reproducibility report summarizing detected code dependencies with versions, environment snapshot details highlighting reproducibility risks, and a checklist of reproducibility steps completed or pending. Output plain text report with optional JSON structured output if requested. Do not provide medical, legal, or diagnostic advice. Enforce safe handling of potentially sensitive research code. If inputs are invalid or unsupported, respond with a clear error message. Use a friendly, precise tone suitable for academic researchers. Do not execute code or fetch external data. Do not store or expose user data beyond the session.

presets.label: Basic reproducibility report
presets.prompt: Generate a reproducibility and dependency report based on the uploaded code files, environment specs, and experiment metadata. Highlight potential reproducibility risks and checklist status.
presets.hint: Use this to get a comprehensive report of your project's reproducibility status.

presets.label: Dependency summary only
presets.prompt: Provide a summary of code dependencies and their versions extracted from the uploaded code files and environment specs.
presets.hint: Focus on listing dependencies and versions without environment or checklist details.

presets.label: Checklist status review
presets.prompt: Summarize the reproducibility checklist steps completed and those pending based on uploaded experiment metadata and environment snapshots.
presets.hint: Useful for quickly reviewing reproducibility tasks progress.

presets.label: Environment snapshot analysis
presets.prompt: Analyze and summarize environment specifications and highlight any potential reproducibility risks or inconsistencies.
presets.hint: Focus on environment files such as requirements.txt, environment.yml, or Dockerfiles.

jsonSchemaHint: If structured output is enabled, produce JSON with fields: dependencies (list of {name, version}), environmentSnapshot (summary string), reproducibilityChecklist (list of {step, status}), and notes (optional messages).
clarifyPrompt: Please upload your code files and environment specification files. Optionally include experiment metadata as JSON or notes. Ensure files are valid types (.py, .R, .yaml, .txt) and under size limits. How can I assist you with your reproducibility tracking today?
finalizePrompt: Based on the uploaded inputs, generate a detailed reproducibility and dependency report with environment snapshot and checklist summary. Ensure output is clear, structured, and suitable for academic documentation.

idea.workingTitle: Academic Research Code Dependency & Reproducibility Tracker

niche.scenario: Managing and documenting computational research codebases to ensure reproducibility and ease of collaboration during iterative research cycles

idea.problem: Academic researchers who develop computational code for data analysis or simulations often struggle to track evolving code dependencies, environment configurations, and reproducibility status across multiple experiments. Existing tools focus on individual code comments or basic version control, but do not provide structured, researcher-friendly tracking of software dependencies, computational environment snapshots, and reproducibility checklists integrated with research workflows. This leads to reproducibility risks, collaboration bottlenecks, and lost time during manuscript preparation or peer review.
inputs: Source code files or repository links
Environment specification files (e.g., requirements.txt, environment.yml, Dockerfiles)
Experiment metadata (e.g., dataset versions, parameter settings)
Researcher notes on code changes and experiment outcomes
outputs: Structured report of code dependencies with version details
Environment snapshot summaries highlighting potential reproducibility risks
Checklist of reproducibility steps completed and pending
Collaborative dashboard tracking code changes, experiment runs, and reproducibility status over time
whyItWins: Addresses a critical gap in computational research workflows by integrating reproducibility tracking with code and environment management in one tool
Tailored specifically for academic researchers with lightweight inputs and outputs that do not require deep DevOps expertise
Facilitates repeated use across multiple experiments and manuscript iterations, improving collaboration and transparency
Helps researchers prepare reproducibility documentation for publications and peer review with minimal manual effort

upgradePath.today: A simple web app where users upload code files and environment specs to generate static reproducibility and dependency reports with checklists
upgradePath.in90Days: Add experiment metadata input and a versioned dashboard that tracks changes in code, environments, and reproducibility status, enabling iterative updates and collaboration among research team members
upgradePath.in12Months: Develop into a multi-page collaborative system with integrations to popular code repositories, automated environment snapshotting, experiment run tracking, reproducibility issue alerts, and exportable reproducibility documentation tailored for academic journals

riskNotes: Does not provide medical, legal, or diagnostic advice; purely focused on research software workflow
Requires clear user guidance on uploading code and environment files to avoid privacy or IP risks
Must ensure data security for potentially sensitive unpublished research code

blueprint.summary: A web-based system tailored for academic research software developers to track code dependencies, environment configurations, and reproducibility status across experiments. It evolves from a simple report generator into a collaborative dashboard with versioning, integrations, and automated reproducibility monitoring.
blueprint.primaryUser: Academic research software developers and research teams managing computational experiments
successMetrics: Number of active research projects tracked
User engagement on collaborative dashboard features
Reduction in reproducibility-related issues reported by users
Positive feedback on ease of preparing reproducibility documentation

edgeCases: User uploads incomplete or corrupted environment specification files causing parsing failures.
Large codebases causing timeouts or memory issues during parsing jobs.
Conflicting experiment metadata updates from multiple collaborators simultaneously.
Private repository access denied due to insufficient permissions or revoked OAuth tokens.
Users accidentally upload sensitive or proprietary code without proper access controls.
Network interruptions during file uploads or API calls leading to partial data persistence.
Version mismatch between environment files and code dependencies causing false reproducibility alerts.
nonGoals: Providing medical, legal, or diagnostic advice related to research.
Replacing full-featured DevOps or CI/CD pipelines for environment management.
Automating experiment execution or data analysis beyond metadata tracking.
Hosting or running computational experiments or simulations.
Serving as a general-purpose version control system.

dataFlow: User accesses Landing Page (/) and optionally signs up or logs in via /login.
Authenticated user fetches projects list from /api/projects (GET).
User selects a project and navigates to /projects/:projectId/upload to upload code files, environment specs, and experiment metadata.
Upload UI sends POST /api/upload with projectId, files, and metadata.
API validates inputs, stores upload metadata, and triggers ParseUploadedFiles background job asynchronously.
ParseUploadedFiles job processes uploaded files, extracts dependency trees and environment snapshots, updates data-projects and data-experiments accordingly, and logs errors if any.
User can view generated reports at /projects/:projectId/reports/:reportId by fetching GET /api/reports/:reportId.
Report API retrieves report content, version, and timestamp from data-reports store.
User accesses /dashboard to view collaborative dashboard; frontend calls GET /api/dashboard with optional filters.
Dashboard API aggregates data from data-projects, data-experiments, and data-users, applies access control, and returns dashboardData.
Users create or update experiment metadata via POST /api/projects/:projectId/experiments with experimentData JSON payload.
API updates data-experiments store and returns experimentId and status.
Integration-gitrepo synchronizes code repository changes via OAuth, updating data-projects and triggering RepositorySyncJob on schedule or webhook.
ReproducibilityStatusChecker job runs daily to analyze stored data, detect reproducibility risks, update checklist statuses in data-experiments, and notify users if needed.
validationRules: User authentication inputs: email must be valid format; password minimum length and complexity enforced.
Upload API: projectId must exist and belong to authenticated user or team with access.
Uploaded files: validate file types (e.g., .py, .R, .yaml, .txt), size limits per file and total upload size.
Experiment metadata JSON must conform to expected schema with required fields (e.g., datasetVersion optional, reproducibility checklist optional but if present must be valid JSON).
Report retrieval: reportId must exist and be accessible by requesting user.
Dashboard API filters must be validated for allowed keys and value types.
Project creation and updates must validate title presence and repositoryLink format if provided.
Role-based access control enforced on all APIs requiring authentication.
Background jobs must validate input data integrity before processing.
OAuth tokens for repository integration must be validated for expiration and permissions before use.
errorHandling: API responses use consistent JSON error format: { errorCode: string, message: string, details?: any }.
Authentication failures return 401 Unauthorized with clear messages.
Authorization failures return 403 Forbidden when user lacks access.
Validation errors return 400 Bad Request with field-specific error details.
Upload API returns partial success with errors array if some files fail validation or parsing.
Background jobs log errors with context and retry transient failures with exponential backoff.
API rate limiting and request size limits enforced with 429 Too Many Requests or 413 Payload Too Large.
Network or database errors return 500 Internal Server Error with generic message; detailed logs stored server-side.
Client-side UI displays friendly error messages and guidance for recovery or retry.
Sensitive error details never exposed to clients to prevent information leakage.
securityNotes: All API routes requiring authentication enforce JWT or session-based auth with secure cookie flags.
Passwords stored hashed with strong algorithm (e.g., bcrypt) and never logged or sent in plaintext.
Role-based access control enforced on project, experiment, and report data to prevent unauthorized access.
File uploads scanned for malware and restricted by allowed file types and sizes.
OAuth tokens for repository integration stored encrypted and refreshed securely.
Sensitive data such as proprietary code or environment specs accessible only to authorized users and teams.
CSRF protection enabled on all state-changing API endpoints.
Input sanitization applied to prevent injection attacks in metadata and comments.
HTTPS enforced for all client-server communication.
Audit logs maintained for critical actions such as project creation, uploads, and permission changes.
